journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology

title-group.article-title: Design of the Grand Touring sports car wing: geometric and aerodynamic twist

contrib-group.aff: Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Edge Hill University, UK

author-notes.corresp: Pascual Marqués-Bruna, Faculty of Arts and Sciences, Edge Hill University, St Helen’s Road, Ormskirk, Lancashire L39 4QP, UK. Email: Marquesp@edgehill.ac.uk

abstract.p: Wing twist gives the Grand Touring sports car an eye-catching ‘aerodynamic shape’. From the functional viewpoint, wing twist may improve downforce, provide stall control and enhance aerodynamic efficiency if the twist is optimised. This study aims, first, to explore the influence of linear geometric and aerodynamic twist upon spanwise upwash velocity, downforce and induced drag distributions and, second, to evaluate the use of optimum twist in achieving minimum induced drag while preserving high downforce, in wings with linear taper for the Grand Touring car. Baseline wing prototypes were designed and fitted, subsequently, with a Gurney flap and endplates to obtain complete wings. Aerodynamics for straight wings and wings with geometric, aerodynamic and optimised twist were computed using modified versions of the Prandtl’s Lifting-line Theory. Straight and geometrically-twisted wings with constituent NACA 651-412 airfoils present superior aerodynamic efficiency at angles of attack ≤ 1° and may be used as stabilisers on high-speed circuits. Geometric twisting elicits a partial, rather than complete, wing stall that contributes to safety in motor racing. A geometrically-twisted wing constructed with a NASA LS(1)-0413 airfoil yields high downforce at the expense of large induced drag via a double-peaked induced drag distribution, and it is suitable for high-downforce racing circuits. Nonetheless, the analysis suggests that a twist-optimised wing for the Grand Touring car very nearly duplicates the ideal aerodynamic performance of an elliptic wing and yields high downforce and minimum possible induced drag. The findings support the implementation of optimum wing twist at the conceptual stages of Grand Touring sports car design.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Modern aeroplane wings are built with a progressive reduction in the angle of incidence, β, from wing root to wing tip (geometric twist consisting of washout) and/or using different airfoil geometries along the span, b, to gradually modify the zero-lift angle of attack,
α
L 0
, of local airfoils (aerodynamic twist).1,2 Both types of twist make the aeroplane look ‘more aerodynamic’ and are important considerations in aircraft design. From the functional viewpoint, wing twist introduces essential performance and safety features, as it helps adjust structural wing loading, reduce induced drag, retain aileron function and control wing stall.1,3,4 In essence, the downwash velocity vector,
w
y
, (upwash in an inverted wing), wing lift coefficient,
−
C
L
, (downforce, in an inverted wing) and wing induced drag coefficient,
C
D i
, distributions vary along
b
to best fit the design purpose of the aeroplane. Similarly, design of the Grand Touring (GT) sports car wing requires optimised aerodynamics to adjust the car to the performance requirements of different racing circuits and improve safety while conforming to the technical regulations for car design prescribed by the Fédération Internationale de l’Automobile (FIA).5,6 However, there is a scarcity of research that investigates the influence of twist upon sports car wing aerodynamics.

Wings with an elliptic planform and no geometric or aerodynamic twist (i.e. straight wings) produce minimum
C
D i
,7 but are more expensive to manufacture than rectangular wings. The tapered wing is typically used as a compromise between the elliptic and the rectangular planform. However, the tapered wing has a lower Reynolds number,
Re
, in the region near the wingtip and tends to stall first in this region, which is undesirable in aircraft.8 Stall control can be achieved using a linear twist distribution,
ω
( θ )
linear
, along
b
, which is uncomplicated to implement if the twist is simply geometric. However, previous research9–12 suggests that linear twist is not the optimum twist distribution for a wing with linear taper. Greater aerodynamic efficiency can be attained by using optimum total twist,
Ω
opt
, combined with an optimum elliptical spanwise twist distribution,
ω
( θ )
opt
, that generate uniform upwash along
b
, an elliptical downforce distribution and minimum induced drag for the wing with linear taper, to yield nearly the same aerodynamic performance as a straight wing of elliptic planform.9

Previous aviation research demonstrates that wing twist introduces desirable aerodynamic and safety qualities, particularly reduced induced drag and stall control.9–12 It is unclear, however, how wing twist may improve aerodynamics and safety of the sports car. Thus, this study aims to:

list-item.p: explore the influence of linear geometric and aerodynamic twist upon spanwise upwash velocity, downforce and induced drag distributions;
evaluate the use of optimum twist to yield high downforce and minimum induced drag in wings with linear taper operating at low Re.

sec.p: The present study uses selected airfoil geometries, wing planform, taper ratio and twist modalities that meet a series of geometrical, size and aerodynamic qualities considered appropriate in the design of the GT car wing. The findings have applications for the implementation of wing twist at the conceptual stages of GT sports car design.

sec.title: Airfoil geometry and wing dimensions
sec.p:
The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA) 651-412 and National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) LS(1)-0413 airfoils were used in the design of wing prototypes.13,14 Airfoil ordinates15,16 were reconstructed using Delcam PowerSHAPE-e 8080 computer-aided design (CAD) software (Figure 1). The design lift coefficient,
c
l 0
, is 0.4 for both airfoils. The
α
L 0
, is −3° and −4° for the 651-412 and LS(1)-0413 airfoils, respectively.16–18 Both airfoils exhibit extensive laminar flow and posses desirable aerodynamic properties.15,18 The small-radius leading edge of the 651-412 makes this airfoil aerodynamically efficient at low incidence.16,17 The LS(1)-0413 airfoil uses a concave pressure recovery that yields high downforce, is stall resistant and can be set above the angle of attack,
α
, for the best downforce-to-drag ratio,
−
C
L
/
C
D
.17,18 Both airfoils are only slightly cambered and, therefore, are suitable for the restricted wing dimensions specified by the FIA.5,17

caption.p: The two airfoils used in the design of the wing prototypes.

sec.title: Wing twist
sec.p:
Linear geometric twist (GeoTwist), linear aerodynamic twist (AeroTwist) and linear combined geometric and aerodynamic twist (GeoAeroTwist) were modelled numerically by gradually modifying β and/or airfoil geometry along
b
(Figure 4). GeoTwist consisted of application of washout using
β
at the wing tips and
β
+ 5° at the mid-span; hence, total twist,
Ω
= 5°.13,14 AeroTwist was simulated by progressively transforming an LS(1)-0413 airfoil at the mid-span station into a 651-412 airfoil at the wing tips; thus, using an airfoil with 1° lower
α
L 0
and a higher
c
l
at the mid-span where the effective angle of attack,
α
eff
, and the circulation,
Γ
( y )
, are greater, in a washin configuration.10,12 GeoAeroTwist consisted of simultaneous spanwise variations in both
β
and airfoil geometry. Two modes of twist optimisation,
ω
( θ )
linear
and
Ω
opt
mode (Semi-Opt) and
ω
( θ )
opt
and
Ω
opt
mode (Optimised), were implemented.6,10 The wing prototypes are described in Table 1. Wing twist and aerodynamic computations were performed using spanwise
n
station intervals of 0.01 m.20

Wing designation according to twist mode, constituent airfoil and wing assembly.

sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the effects of constituent airfoil and linear twist mode on
w
y
distribution for the baseline wings. The GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 B wing generates the highest
w
y
along b. Geometric twisting is the most influential design parameter in the generation of
w
y
.

Spanwise
w
y
distribution in the baseline wings.

Spanwise
−
C
L
and
C

distributions
sec.p:
Linear twist causes a deviation from an ideal elliptical
−
C
L
distribution (Figures 6 and 7). The shapes of the
−
C
L
distribution in the baseline wings include elliptical, quasi-elliptical and single-peaked and the shapes of the
C
D i
distribution encompass single trough, smooth trough and double-peaked. An elliptical
−
C
L
distribution yields a single trough
C
D i
distribution, a quasi-elliptical
−
C
L
distribution generates a smooth trough
C
D i
distribution, and a single-peaked
−
C
L
distribution produces a double-peaked
C
D i
distribution. Total wing
C
D i
for the baseline wings is presented in Table 2, based on
α
= 5°.

sec.title: Downforce and aerodynamic efficiency
sec.p: The drag polars for the complete wings show that the GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 C and the GeoAeroTwisted C wings are superior as downforce-generating surfaces, at the expense of greater drag (Figure 8). In Figure 8, the data for the GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 C at α of −4°, 5° and 12° have been emphasised to illustrate the influence of α on aerodynamic data. The AeroTwisted C wing attains greater downforce than the Straight 651-412 C wing, but adds extra drag.

caption.p:
Drag polars for the complete wings (–4° ≤
α
≤ 12°).

sec.p:
Figure 9 reveals the higher aerodynamic efficiency of the Straight 651-412 C and GeoTwisted 651-412 C wings over the full range of
α
; whereby, the peak
−
C
L
/
C
D
corresponds to
α
≤ 1°. The GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 C and GeoAeroTwisted C wings are most efficient at low incidence, –4° ≤
α
≤ –2°. Wings that incorporate the LS(1)-0413 airfoil are aerodynamically less efficient.

caption.p:
−
C
L
/
C
D
for the complete wings.

sec.title: Twist optimisation
sec.p:
Figure 10 shows linear and optimised twist distributions for a baseline wing configuration. The optimised twist distribution adopts an elliptical profile. Aerodynamic parameters of the Semi-Opt LS(1)-0413 B and Optimised LS(1)-0413 B wings are shown in Table 3. Compared to the Semi-Opt LS(1)-0413 B, the Optimised LS(1)-0413 B allows 1° larger
Ω
opt
and yields a lower
C
Di
opt
for the given
−
C
L
of 0.77. Installation of the Gurney flap in the Optimised LS(1)-0413 G results in enhanced downforce; however, the Gurney flap incurs a drag penalty (Table 4). The use of end plates in the Optimised LS(1)-0413 C helps obtain additional downforce, reduce drag and enhance
−
C
L
/
C
D
.

caption.p: Normalised linear and elliptical twist distributions.

Aerodynamic parameters of the Semi-Opt LS(1)-0413 B and Optimised LS(1)-0413 B wings (based on
−
C
L
= 0.77).
Aerodynamic parameters of the Optimised LS(1)-0413 B, G and C wings.

fn.p: wy obtained at the wing mid-span station and measured in (wy /V∞) × 100.
B: baseline wing; G: wing fitted with a Gurney flap; C: complete wing.

sec.title: Upwash distribution
sec.p:
Directly related to
−
C
L
, spanwise
w
y
distribution is largely determined by airfoil type and twist mode. The LS(1)-0413 airfoil yields higher upwash velocity and downforce, and it is thus superior for the construction of a high-downforce wing. In a straight wing, the upwash is spread elliptically along
b
. However, geometric twist concentrates the upwash at the mid-span due to the high α (i.e.
β
+ 5°) in this region (Figure 5) and may reduce the ability of the end plates to enhance the effective
AR
of the wing.7,13 The upwash configuration determines the flow characteristics encountered by pursuing cars drafting in the wake of the leading car and has implications for car performance and handling.13 A wide wake uniformly-spread along b would present more stable flow conditions and facilitate the handling of the pursuing car. The GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 B and GeoAeroTwisted B wings concentrate the upwash at the mid-span and may thus present a narrower wake that deters pursuing cars from drafting in close proximity to the leading car.13,14

sec.title:
Spanwise
−
C
L
and
C
D i
distributions
sec.p:
Use of the LS(1)-0413 airfoil for wing construction results in higher downforce primarily due to the larger leading edge radius and 1% greater thickness than in the 651-412 airfoil;16–18 however, such geometric features of the LS(1)-0413 airfoil augment induced drag (Figure 6). Straight wings yield an elliptical
−
C
L
distribution, linear development of
C
D i
along
b
and zero induced drag at the mid-span station. In contrast, geometric twist augments
−
C
L
due to the higher α at the mid-span but causes the
−
C
L
distribution to deviate from elliptical into a single-peaked distribution and a consequent increase in
C
D i
through a wavy double-peaked
C
D i
pattern.1,4,7,8 Specifically, total wing
C
D i
increases from 0.0045 (lowest value) in the Straight 651-412 B to 0.0110 in the GeoTwisted 651-412 B and from 0.0074 in the Straight LS(1)-0413 B to 0.0155 (highest value) in the GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 B (Table 2). Unlike in a straight wing, linear twist produces induced drag at the mid-span (Figures 6 and 7). This is expected, as theory determines that a twisted wing will generate induced drag even when set at
α
L 0
.10,11,20 Geometric twist facilitates a partial wing stall since the mid-span region, which is set at higher
α
, will stall first.3,19 Partial wing stall is an important design parameter in aviation that may also contribute to safety in motor racing.1,3,13 Should the wing stall as the Re decreases when the car decelerates upon entering a slow curve, a partial wing stall, rather than a complete stall, will incur a gradual development of the stall and prevent a sudden loss of downforce. Nonetheless, greater safety, as well as higher downforce, is attained by using the LS(1)-0413 airfoil, which is stall resistant.17,18 AeroTwist causes a subtle deviation from an elliptical
−
C
L
distribution into a quasi-elliptical distribution (Figure 7). In the AeroTwisted B wing, the total wing
C
D i
(0.0071) is less than in the Straight LS(1)-0413 B (
C
D i
= 0.0074) (Table 2). The increase in
C
D i
at the mid-span via a smooth trough
C
D i
pattern in the AeroTwisted B wing is less severe than when using geometric twist (Figures 6 and 7). The GeoAeroTwisted B wing reveals the high-downforce capability of the LS(1)-0413 airfoil located at the mid-span and set at large α (i.e.
β
+ 5°) that yields a steep single-peaked
−
C
L
distribution. However, the combined twist of the GeoAeroTwisted B wing incurs a large induced drag penalty (total
C
D i
= 0.0151) in the form of a double-peaked
C
D i
profile. The analysis of spanwise
−
C
L
and
C
D i
distributions shows that higher downforce can be attained by using an LS(1)-0413 airfoil and by twisting the wing. However, downforce augmentation in the GT car using non-optimised linear wing twist incurs a large induced drag penalty that is considered too severe in the design of aeroplane wings.2,3,7,19 The large induced drag slows the car down in the straight sections of a high-speed racing circuit. However, the car designer may consider that, in a high-downforce racing circuit that contains slow turns, the additional downforce achieved by linearly twisting the wing should compensate for the performance losses caused by the extra induced drag.6,13,14

sec.title: Downforce and aerodynamic efficiency
sec.p:
The data in Figures 8 and 9 help prioritise either downforce or aerodynamic efficiency in wing design according to the characteristics of the racing circuit.13,14 Greater downforce is attained using geometric twist at the expense of greater drag. The higher aerodynamic efficiency of the Straight 651-412 C and GeoTwisted 651-412 C wings over the full range of
α
(Figure 9) is due to the small-radius leading edge and 1% thinner profile of the constituent airfoil.15,16 The peak
−
C
L
/
C
D
corresponds, however, to
α
≤ 1°, which is desirable for a wing used as a stabiliser in a high-speed racing circuit, but is impractical if high downforce generation is the design precedence.13,14 The AeroTwisted C wing is complex to construct but attains greater efficiency than the Straight LS(1)-0413 C. Thus, the reference data in Figures 8 and 9 help select constituent airfoil, linear twist mode and α to fine tune the car for particular racing circuits.

sec.title: Twist optimisation
sec.p:
The findings suggest that
ω
( θ )
opt
twist mode generates an elliptical upwash distribution.9 A difference of 2.1 (
w
y
/
V
∞
) × 100 in upwash velocity at the mid-span between the GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 B and Optimised LS(1)-0413 C wings (Figure 5 and Table 4) indicates a more uniform upwash distribution along b in the Optimised LS(1)-0413 C.9 In the Optimised LS(1)-0413 G, the Gurney flap forces the wake upwards and is primarily responsible for increased downforce (Table 4) with further increments in downforce achieved by the installation of end plates in the Optimised LS(1)-0413 C.22,23 The use of end plates in the Optimised LS(1)-0413 C reduces Oswald efficiency (Table 4); however, the augmented effective
AR
compensates for the additional
C
D i
opt
and
C
D
incurred by the Gurney flap and helps achieve a high
−
C
L
/
C
D
of 19.4.3,4,19 Thus,
ω
( θ )
opt
twist mode complements the use of end plates to obtain a high-downforce aerodynamically-efficient wing for the GT car.

The findings support the theory that postulates that a wing with optimum twist produces less induced drag than a straight wing of the same planform and
AR
, at downforce coefficients greater than one-half the design downforce coefficient.9,10 Accordingly,
C
D i
for the Straight LS(1)-0413 B is 0.0074 and
C
D i
opt
for the Optimised LS(1)-0413 B is 0.0036 (Tables 2 and 3). This is because, with the exception of an elliptic planform, a straight wing is optimised for a design downforce coefficient of zero.4,9 However, Optimised twist considerably reduces induced drag when a wing operates at downforce coefficients other than zero.9,10 Thus, the findings suggest that a twist-optimised wing with a linearly-tapered planform for the GT car very nearly duplicates the performance of an elliptic wing and satisfies the requirement for minimum possible induced drag, consonant with theory.7,9,11,20 In terms of aerodynamic performance,
Ω
opt
is better than
Ω
and
ω
( θ )
opt
is superior to
ω
( θ )
linear
. Use of
Ω
= 5° in the GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 B wing yields a total
C
D i
of 0.0155; however, use of
ω ( θ
)
linear
and
Ω
opt
= 3.4° in the Semi-Opt LS(1)-0413 B wing gives
C
D i
opt
= 0.0130 for the same
−
C
L
of 0.77 (Tables 2 and 4). When using
ω
( θ )
opt
, the twist distribution becomes elliptical (Figure 10) and, therefore, the difference
α −

L 0
remains large for a considerable proportion of
b
. The Semi-Opt LS(1)-0413 B wing shows a lower
k
D 0
and a higher
C
D i
opt
than the Optimised LS(1)-0413 B wing (Table 3) due to the aerodynamically less effective twist that influences factors
ε
Ω
and
k
DL
and results in a 1° smaller
Ω
opt
required to find the minimum possible
C
D i
. Factors
ε
Ω
and
k
DL
in both the Semi-Opt LS(1)-0413 B and Optimised LS(1)-0413 B wings are higher than for a wing with an elliptic planform due to the relatively small taper ratio of 0.9 used in the design of the prototype wings (Figure 2).7,9 However, the small taper ratio helps maintain chord length and prevent a low
Re
and the stall in the wing tip region.8 In the Optimised LS(1)-0413 C wing,
−
C
L
is 0.18 greater,
C
D
is 0.0107 lower and
−

L
/
C
D
is 5.0 higher than in the GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 C wing at
α
= 5° (Table 4 and Figures 8 and 9). Wing
ω
( θ )
opt
and
Ω
opt
mode is implemented by elliptically varying the function
α −
α
L 0
along the span (Figure 10) and can be attained by means of elliptic geometric twist, aerodynamic twist, or both simultaneously.9,10,12 Using a twist-optimised wing enhances aerodynamic performance but increases the complexity of wing construction, particularly when using combined geometric and aerodynamic twist, as the twist varies non-linearly along
b
. However, a wing of complex shape and twist may be aesthetically more appealing to the car designer.13

The present study is limited to the selected airfoil geometries (Figure 1), the wing planform, taper ratio and linear twist modes shown in Figures 2 and 4 and the twist optimisation of the LS(1)-0413 wing configuration. However, the possibilities for wing construction within the FIA technical regulations5 are endless and open to innovative design. Phillips et al.11 demonstrated the validity of the modified lifting-line numerical solution9–12 for the prediction of induced drag associated with optimised wing twist. The computational fluid dynamics (CFD) validation performed by Phillips et al.11 suggests that the lifting-line method slightly underestimates the decrease in induced drag achieved by optimum twist. Nonetheless, the complexity of flow over both the linearly-twisted and optimally-twisted wings fitted with a Gurney flap and end plates may be examined in a wind tunnel to further validate the numerical methods. Future studies may use CFD techniques to examine how the presence of the car in front of the wing influences the airflow passing over the twisted wing and end plates.6 An interesting alternative to wing twist for the GT car is the use of full-span ‘twisterons’ developed by Phillips et al.10 that simultaneously provide high downforce and minimum induced drag. More recently, the use of a flexible wing has been suggested for sports cars.6 The flexible wing is optimised for minimum induced drag in the high-speed sections of the racing circuit by passively reducing α, however the wing maintains a high α and high downforce in low-speed turns.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The numerical analysis suggests that wing twist in the GT car improves downforce, provides stall control and enhances aerodynamic efficiency if the twist is optimised. The Straight 651-412 C and GeoTwisted 651-412 C wings present superior aerodynamic efficiency. However, the peak
−
C
L
/
C
D
occurs at
α
≤ 1°, which is only practical when the wings are used as stabilisers in high-speed circuits. Geometric twist augments downforce due to higher α at the mid-span, but yields a single-peaked
−
C
L
distribution that increases induced drag. Geometric twist concentrates the upwash at the mid-span and may adversely influence end plate effectiveness. However, should the wing stall, geometric twist helps achieve a partial – rather than a complete – stall that contributes to safety in motor racing. A GeoTwisted LS(1)-0413 C wing yields high downforce, at the expense of large induced drag, and is suitable for a high-downforce racing circuit. In an Optimised LS(1)-0413 B wing,
C
D i
is 0.0038 less than in a Straight LS(1)-0413 B, for a constant
−
C
L
of 0.77. Thus, the findings suggest that a twist-optimised wing of tapered planform for the GT car very closely replicates the aerodynamic performance of an elliptic wing and fulfils the requirement for high downforce and minimum possible induced drag.
